{{refimprove|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Clara Petacci | image = Clara Petacci.png | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1912|02|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Rome]], Italy | death_date = {{Death date and age|1945|04|28|1912|02|28|df=y}} | death_place = [[Giulino di Mezzegra]], Italy | nationality = Italian | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = Being the mistress of Benito Mussolini | relatives = [[Miriam di San Servolo]] (sister) Marcello Petacci (brother) }} '''Clara Petacci''', known as '''Claretta Petacci''' ({{IPA-it|klaˈretta peˈtattʃi|lang}}; 28 February 1912 – 28 April 1945), was a [[Mistress (lover)|mistress]] of the Italian dictator [[Benito Mussolini]] and was executed with him by [[Italian resistance|partisans]].
==Family== Clara Petacci's father was Dr. Francesco Petacci, primary physician of Pope [[Pius XI]]. Her sister was actress [[Miriam di San Servolo]] (31 May 1923 – 24 May 1991), also known as Miriam Petacci or Miriam Day. Petacci's brother, Marcello Petacci, was captured with Mussolini and Petacci. However, rather than being executed in [[Dongo (CO)|Dongo]], he was shot while trying to escape. [[File:Mussolini e Petacci a Piazzale Loreto, 1945.jpg|thumb|The corpses of [[Nicola Bombacci|Bombacci]], [[Benito Mussolini|Mussolini]], Clara Petacci, [[Alessandro Pavolini|Pavolini]] and [[Achille Starace|Starace]] in [[Piazzale Loreto]], 1945]]
==Relationship with Mussolini== Petacci had a long-standing relationship with Mussolini while he was married to [[Rachele Mussolini]]. Petacci was 28 years younger than Mussolini.<ref>{{in lang|es}} Giuseppina Persichetti, ''La enamorada de Mussolini'', Madrid, Ediciones Caballero Audaz, 1947.</ref>
Part of their correspondence is still the subject of a dispute with the National Archives,{{which|date=March 2018}} based on privacy.<ref>{{in lang|it}} Giampiero Buonomo, [https://www.academia.edu/11435982/Ricerca_storiografica_e_diritto_alla_riservatezza {{lang|it|Quel carteggio tra Mussolini e la Petacci. Storici sacrificati sull’altare della privacy}}, in Diritto e giustizia, 16 luglio 2005].</ref>
==Death== {{See also|Death of Benito Mussolini}} On 27 April 1945, Mussolini and Petacci were captured by [[Italian resistance movement|partisans]] while traveling with a convoy of [[Italian Social Republic]] members.<ref>Gunther Langes, ''Auf Wiedersehen Claretta. Il diario dell'uomo che poteva salvare Mussolini e la Petacci, a cura di Nico Pirozzi'', Villaricca, Edizioni Cento Autori, 2012. {{ISBN|978-88-97121-37-4}}.</ref>
On 28 April, she and Mussolini were taken to [[Mezzegra]] and shot. On the following day, the bodies of Mussolini and Petacci were taken to the [[Piazzale Loreto]] in [[Milan]] and hung upside down in front of a petrol station. The bodies were photographed as a crowd vented their rage upon them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cidc.library.cornell.edu/dof/italy/captioned/hanging.htm |title=Death of the Father-Mussolini & Fascist Italy: the 'infamous' exhibit |publisher=[[Cornell Institute for Digital Collections]] |year=1999}}</ref>
==In popular culture== *''[[Claretta]]'', 1984 film starring [[Claudia Cardinale]] *[[:it:Clara Petacci#Claretta nel cinema|Other films]] *The American [[Punk Rock]] band [[Against Me!]] reference Petacci's execution in their song "[[Osama bin Laden as the Crucified Christ]]" from their 2014 album ''[[Transgender Dysphoria Blues]]'' *The American musician [[Scott Walker (singer)|Scott Walker]] recorded a song about Petacci called "Clara" on his 2006 album ''[[The Drift]]'' *''[[Mussolini: The Untold Story]]'', 1985 TV-miniseries featured [[Virginia Madsen]] as Petacci * ''[[Mussolini and I]]'', in which she is played by [[Barbara De Rossi]]
